trans-unit.source: Getting Started using docker with swarm on Azure
trans-unit.target: Getting Started using docker with swarm on Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how to create a group of VMs with the Docker VM Extension and use swarm to create a Docker cluster.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to create a group of VMs with the Docker VM Extension and use swarm to create a Docker cluster.

trans-unit.source: How to use docker with swarm
trans-unit.target: How to use docker with swarm

trans-unit.source: This topic shows a very simple way to use [docker](https://www.docker.com/) with [swarm](https://github.com/docker/swarm) to create a swarm-managed cluster on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows a very simple way to use [docker](https://www.docker.com/) with [swarm](https://github.com/docker/swarm) to create a swarm-managed cluster on Azure.

trans-unit.source: It creates four virtual machines in Azure, one to act as the swarm manager, and three as part of the cluster of docker hosts.
trans-unit.target: It creates four virtual machines in Azure, one to act as the swarm manager, and three as part of the cluster of docker hosts.

trans-unit.source: When you are finished, you can use swarm to see the cluster and then begin to use docker on it.
trans-unit.target: When you are finished, you can use swarm to see the cluster and then begin to use docker on it.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the Azure CLI calls in this topic use the service management (asm) mode.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the Azure CLI calls in this topic use the service management (asm) mode.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This is an early version of software, so check back for updates about using this on Azure to create large, balanced, and controlled clusters of Docker containers, as well as checking the docker swarm documentation to discover all its features.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This is an early version of software, so check back for updates about using this on Azure to create large, balanced, and controlled clusters of Docker containers, as well as checking the docker swarm documentation to discover all its features.

trans-unit.source: > In addition, this topic uses docker with swarm and the Azure CLI *without* using **docker-machine** in order to show how the different tools work together but remain independent.
trans-unit.target: > In addition, this topic uses docker with swarm and the Azure CLI *without* using **docker-machine** in order to show how the different tools work together but remain independent.

trans-unit.source: **docker-machine** has **--swarm** switches that enable you to use **docker-machine** to directly add nodes to a swarm.
trans-unit.target: **docker-machine** has **--swarm** switches that enable you to use **docker-machine** to directly add nodes to a swarm.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see the [docker-machine](https://github.com/docker/machine) documentation.
trans-unit.target: For an example, see the [docker-machine](https://github.com/docker/machine) documentation.

trans-unit.source: If you missed **docker-machine** running against Azure VMs, see [How to use docker-machine with Azure](virtual-machines-docker-machine.md).
trans-unit.target: If you missed **docker-machine** running against Azure VMs, see [How to use docker-machine with Azure](virtual-machines-docker-machine.md).

trans-unit.source:
Create docker hosts with Azure Virtual Machines
This topic creates four VMs, but you can use any number you want.
trans-unit.target:
Create docker hosts with Azure Virtual Machines
This topic creates four VMs, but you can use any number you want.

trans-unit.source: Call the following with *<password>* replaced by the password you have chosen.
trans-unit.target: Call the following with *<password>* replaced by the password you have chosen.

source.ph: azure vm docker create swarm-master -l "East US" -e 22 $imagename ops

target.ph: azure vm docker create swarm-master -l "East US" -e 22 $imagename ops

trans-unit.source:
When you're done you should be able to use **azure vm list** to see your Azure VMs:
$ azure vm list | grep "swarm-[mn]" data: swarm-master ReadyRole East US swarm-master.cloudapp.net 100.78.186.65 data: swarm-node-1 ReadyRole East US swarm-node-1.cloudapp.net 100.66.72.126 data: swarm-node-2 ReadyRole East US swarm-node-2.cloudapp.net 100.72.18.47 data: swarm-node-3 ReadyRole East US swarm-node-3.cloudapp.net 100.78.24.68

## Installing swarm on the swarm master VM
This topic uses the [container model of installation from the docker swarm documentation](https://github.com/docker/swarm#1---docker-image) -- but you could also SSH to the **swarm-master**.

trans-unit.source: In this model, **swarm** is downloaded as a docker container running swarm.
trans-unit.target: In this model, **swarm** is downloaded as a docker container running swarm.

trans-unit.source: Below, we perform this step *remotely from our laptop by using docker* to connect to the **swarm-master** VM and tell it to use the cluster id creation command, **swarm create**.
